p: The agar well diffusion method (CLSI) was used to screen for antibacterial activity of the leaves with reference strains ( Escherichia coli ATCC 25922, Salmonella typhi ATCC 19430, Pseudomonas aeruginosa ATCC 27853 and Staphylococcus aureus ATCC 25923, and a Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus strain) as well as the MDR clinical isolates from the wounds ( E. coli, P. aeruginosa, S. aureus and CoNS). About three to four isolated colonies of similar morphology were picked from the 18–24 h agar plate of pure cultures using a sterile loop, and then inoculated individually into 4 mL peptone broth (Sigma, P0556, Sigma-Aldrich Inc., St. Louis, MO, USA). The density/turbidity of the inoculum was adjusted to 0.5 McFarland turbidity standard, resulting in a suspension of 1.5 × 10 8 CFU colony forming units.
